Award.AwardTitle: Geometry of Deformation and Moduli Spaces of Complex Manifolds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1510216, Principal Investigator: Kefeng Liu

Deformation theory, moduli spaces and modular forms are fundamental to many subjects of mathematics and physics from geometry, topology, algebraic geometry, number theory to theoretical physics like string theory and cosmology. Many deep results in mathematics and string theory crucially rely on moduli spaces, which describe large families of geometric structures within a related geometric space, which is sometimes larger and less directly defined than the original geometry. A simple example is the collection of isometry classes of metric structures on a circle - these are determined by the circumference of the circle and so correspond to the open line of all positive real numbers; in this example a deformation would be an expansion or contraction of one circle to another of larger or smaller circumference. Understanding of deformations and moduli spaces of projective manifolds from global geometric point of view will reveal deep connections among geometry, algebra and physics, will have fundamental impacts in many research fields in mathematics and physics.

The principal investigator will study the geometric and topological structures of the deformation theory, Teichmuller and moduli spaces of projective manifolds, and the modularity of certain generating series of the dimension of the tautological rings on the moduli spaces of Riemann surfaces. More precisely, the PI will study the following three important problems: (1) using the new formulas and iteration method discovered by the PI and collaborators to systemically study global deformation theory and prove deformation invariance of the dimension of pluricanonical sections of Kahler manifolds as conjectured by Siu by explicit geometric constructions; (2) proving a conjecture of Griffiths, which asserts the existence of simultaneous uniformization of all the periods for a family of projective manifolds; (3) exploring a striking relation discovered by the PI and Hao Xu between the Ramanujan mock theta-function and the dimensions of the tautological ring of moduli spaces of Riemann surfaces. In carrying out the projects the PI will train several young students and postdoctors to conduct research in these projects through collaboration, seminars, and lectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Deformation theory, moduli spaces and modular forms are among the most important objects for both mathematics and theoretical physics. They have been studied in differential geometry, topology, number theory and algebraic geometry, and they have many fundamental applications in these and many other subjects. The understanding of the deep relations between moduli spaces and modular forms has been important for the developments of both mathematical and the physical theories. In string theory, many fundamental partition functions can be reduced to geometric or topological invariants on the moduli paces, which in many cases have remarkable symmetry of modularity. Understanding of deformations and moduli spaces of projective manifolds from global geometric point of view will reveal deep connections among geometry, algebra and physics, will have fundamental impacts in many research fields in mathematics and physics.  Our research projects, while building on many of the my previous and current works, involve techniques and knowledges from several major active research areas in mathematics in connection to geometry and topology, such as mirror symmetry, Calabi-Yau manifolds and their moduli spaces, complex analysis, complex geometry and deformation theory, modular forms and variations of Hodge structures. 

 Under the support of the NSF grant 1510216, we have developed a new global method to treat the extensions of certain natural geometric objects, which are called holomorphic forms and holomorphic pluricanonical forms, and obtained global canonical sections of certain natural bundles on the moduli spaces of projective manifolds. We are able to apply the results to the study of global geometric structures of the moduli spaces of Calabi-Yau manifolds and general complex manifolds. We also obtained a new method to solve the measurable Beltrami equations for quasi-conformal maps by using Hodge theory which is the most fundamental equation in complex analysis. Our results lead to a rather deep understanding of several important  conjectures in geometry and will have strong impacts on several major subjects of differential and algebraic geometry. 

 In carrying out the projects the I have trained several young students and postdoctors to conduct research in the proposed projects, through collaboration, seminars and lectures. For the past several years the I have presented many lectures worldwide on various results related to the research projects. I have also co-organized many workshops and summer schools in several main streams of mathematics and string theory. Many leading mathematicians and string theorists and many students and young researchers from the US and around the world have attended these conferences and summer schools. Through these activities many young students and scholars have started to do research in these fields. In recent years I have been teaching the graduate course ”Geometry and Physics” every year at UCLA, and has also lectured on several topic courses at UCLA in geometry and physics related to the projects, and have written up several lecture notes through these courses which are being polished into published books.
